title: No retreat, no surrender on budget hold-out
text:
This new round of political Chicken Little is due to the latest IMF forecasts that growth will slow to 1.7 per cent in Australia this year, down 0.4 per cent from its previous forecast.

Holding the line: Prime Minister Scott Morrison and Treasurer Josh Frydenberg. Alex Ellinghausen

Labor is trying to hide its own political relief as it contrasts the government’s “complacency” with its own willingness in office to follow the advice of then Treasury Secretary Ken Henry to “go early, go hard, go households” in response to the global financial crisis.

“This government is going slowly, going soft and going nowhere when it comes to an economic plan,” Opposition Leader Anthony Albanese declared. This charge does, of course, recall the rather unhappy legacy of Labor’s era in government as well as the party’s spectacular inability to persuade voters last May of the benefits of its own economic plan.

But it gives Labor a chance to argue the next round of tax cuts should be brought forward to help a “floundering economy” – a counter to relentless Coalition mockery about the disastrous economic impact of the opposition’s high-taxing alternative.

Despite the opposition’s criticisms, it’s hard to finger the Morrison government for particular ineptitude given the Australian economy is part of a global “synchronised slowdown”, as described by the IMF, and provoked by much larger forces, including one Donald Trump and his trade war with China.

But the argument over the urgent need for greater fiscal stimulus is certainly not confined to domestic political partisanship. Just ask Philip Lowe. Even if he’s more polite about it than Albanese, it’s clear the Reserve Bank governor doesn’t think relying on lower interest rates and government as usual from the Coalition will be enough to get inflation up and unemployment down. And that’s with RBA growth forecasts, like those of Treasury, still being considerably more optimistic than those of the IMF World Economic Outlook.

Former Treasurer Peter Costello, the deficit-cutting supremo of the 1990s, is certainly not in favour of more spending. But he backs Lowe’s argument about the much-reduced impact of monetary policy these days, telling a conference on Wednesday it has “run its race” .

Advertisement

So what comes in its place? Promised structural reforms are still only promises and with a long time frame.

The Morrison government’s refusal to change course on spending leaves Frydenberg arguing a “strong budget position is not mutually exclusive from having a strong economy”. The catch is the domestic economy is clearly not strong enough despite the big increase in jobs over the last several years.

Morrison cites the advantages of “stable and disciplined financial management” compared with the “reckless spending and waste” of Labor in government operating in panic and crisis. He points to various scandals like Labor’s “overpriced” school halls and pink batts program.

It’s still obvious IMF forecasts don’t make happy bedtime reading for any Australian treasurer, even if most of the developed world’s other finance ministers, from Greece to Germany, would be just about as miserable. Australia’s expected growth comes in at 19th position out of the 34 OECD countries.

The IMF has called on all governments to use a combination of spending and structural reforms to lift economic growth and international trade.

"Monetary policy cannot be the only game in town. It should be coupled with fiscal support where fiscal space is available, and policy is not already too expansionary," the IMF said.

In that global context, Australia’s budget surplus looks anything but overly expansionary – rather the reverse.

Advertisement

Innes Willox, chief executive of the Australian Industry Group, was particularly blunt about what he thinks is required.

“Our economy needs a spark to regain momentum and rebuild confidence to combat the local and international pressures which are a drag on business and consumer confidence,” he declared.

"It is time for Australia’s governments – at the federal, state, territory and local levels – to work more effectively together to impart a more active stimulus than is currently in the pipeline. There is a clear place for a sensible acceleration of ‘shovel-ready’ infrastructure investment and public works. There is also a strong case to closely consider bringing forward the scheduled program of income tax relief.”

The federal government is stressing it wants to work with the states on rolling out a decade-long, $100 billion pipeline of infrastructure projects "as quickly as possible" but cautions about capacity constraints and the need to look at smaller projects and upgrades.

Anyone for more tax cuts?
description: Josh Frydenberg and Scott Morrison are trying to polish a political message looking ever more battered by economic reality.
